benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails - Add account email

covered: Valid Payload: Happy-path scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05) verify successful creation and 201 responses and Location header.
Invalid Payload / Validation: Malformed JSON (TC10), missing required fields (TC11), invalid email format (TC12), empty body (TC17) are covered.
Path parameter validation: Invalid UUID format (TC07), missing accountId (TC08), and non-existent account (TC09) are covered.
Headers: Required header presence and behavior tested (TC05, TC13); optional headers X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment tested (TC02).
Server-side failures: External dependency / DB unavailable behaviour is covered (TC15).
Security & Input-sanitization: SQL injection and XSS attempts are covered (TC23, TC24).
Boundary & robustness: Large payload/boundary test (TC16), concurrency (TC20), transient network/retry (TC25), and slow DB/response-time considerations (TC19) are included.
Integration & downstream consistency: Visibility via subsequent GET and propagation to downstream systems is addressed (TC26).
Regression & backward compatibility: Unicode/special chars and older API version compatibility are present (TC21, TC22).
Documentation & accessibility: Error message clarity and docs checked (TC27).
gaps: Duplicate submission / idempotency / conflict handling: No explicit test for submitting the same exact AccountEmail twice and asserting 409 or graceful de-duplication behavior.

Exact schema/response shape and headers: While responses are checked for presence of objects and Location header, there is no explicit verification of response Content-Type, full AccountEmail schema fields, or detailed response body structure (e.g., createdDate, id) against the definition.
Produce/Consume headers: No explicit tests asserting request Content-Type application/json and response Content-Type application/json.

HTTP 5xx server error variations: TC15 covers dependency down (503) but there are no tests for generic 500 Internal Server Error behavior or structured error payloads when unexpected server errors occur.
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests for rate limits / repeated rapid requests to observe 429 behavior.
Duplicate-email business rule: No scenario covering adding an email identical to an existing one for the same account and expecting a business-specific response (e.g., 409 or ignore).
Concrete performance thresholds: TC19 notes measuring response time but lacks concrete SLA assertions and automated checks for acceptable thresholds.
Content-negotiation and caching: No tests for caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or behavior when Accept headers vary (though caching may be more relevant to GET).
Authorization nuance: TC14 covers unauthorized access, but there is no explicit test for insufficient scope/roles (403 vs 401) or token expiry handling.
recommendations: Add a duplicate-submission test: POST the same AccountEmail twice and assert correct API behavior (409 conflict or idempotent response), and ensure the DB has one record only.
Add strict response-schema assertions: Verify response Content-Type, presence and types of all AccountEmail fields (id, createdDate, isPrimary, etc.), and validate Location URL format.
Include Content-Type negotiation tests: Send requests without or with incorrect Content-Type and assert 400; assert response Content-Type is application/json.
Add generic server-error tests: Simulate unexpected server exceptions to validate 500 responses and error payload format.
Add rate-limiting tests: Hammer endpoint to verify proper throttling and 429 responses (if the API enforces rate limits).

Add business-rule tests for duplicate email addresses and primary-email constraints: e.g., attempting to add an already-existing email for the same account or marking multiple primary emails should produce defined errors.
Make performance checks concrete: For TC19, add SLA thresholds (e.g., 95% requests < X ms) and automated assertions for acceptable latencies.
Extend authorization tests: Cover expired tokens, insufficient-role (403) scenarios, and token scopes if applicable.
If applicable, add caching/content-negotiation checks even though caching is typically GET-focused; ensure POST responses do not incorrectly set cacheable headers.
